job.name: SQL_Pooled_Connection_Update

variable.name: RDBMS_NAME
variable.model: PA:LIST(postgresql, mysql, greenplum, sqlserver, oracle, hsqldb)
variable.description: The relational database management system name e.g. postgresql, mysql, greenplum, hsqldb, oracle...

variable.name: HOST
variable.description: Hostname or IP address of the database host machine. Default value is localhost

variable.name: PORT
variable.description: The listening port of the database

variable.name: CREDENTIALS_KEY
variable.description: Third-party credential storing the password associated with the given user name

variable.name: POOL_autoCommit
variable.description: HikariCP offers many data source properties that can be used to configure the DB pooled connection such as autoCommit, maximumPoolSize, maxLifetime, idleTimeout .... You can add as many properties as you want. For each one, add a new task variable where the variable name is the property name having POOL_ as a prefix (e.g. POOL_autoCommit, POOL_maximumPoolSize) and the variable value is the property value. For more info, please refer to HikariCP documentation.

variable.name: SQL_STATEMENTS
variable.description: A string composed of a set of update statements (CREATE, INSERT , UPDATE , or DELETE statement)

job.description: This workflow is a template that demonstrates how to use pooled connections to SQL databases across multiple SQL tasks (basically when running several Tasks concurrently on the same machine). The workflow is composed of a single task Open_Pooled_Connection_and_Execute_Update.

task.name: Open_Pooled_Connection_and_Execute_Update
task.description: This task allows to open a pooled connection to any SQL database and then execute any SQL update statements on it. If it requires a password, you have to add it using the following third-party credential: {key: rdbms_name://<username>@<host>, value: RDBMS_PASSWORD}. Please refer to the User documentation to learn how to add third-party credentials. This task has the same list of workflow variables.
